intro: Prionosciadium pringlei, commonly known as the Hawaiian ghostflower, is a rare and endangered flowering plant native to the Hawaiian Islands. It is a member of the Apiaceae family, characterized by its umbellate inflorescence and aromatic foliage. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded habitats such as mesic forests and stream banks. It has small, white to pale yellow flowers and is known for its delicate, ephemeral blooms. Due to habitat loss and invasive species, conservation efforts are crucial for its survival.
